text: The lumps on the skin are likely caused by a skin condition called reactive arythemia, which is triggered by a hot shower or bath, and itchy clothing. It is important to avoid scratching the skin, as it can make the lumps more pronounced. To help ease the itching, you can use an ice pack or a cool, wet cloth on the affected areas. In addition, avoid hot showers and tight-fitting clothes to prevent further irritation. Applying a topical cream or ointment, such as calamine or hydrocortisone, can also provide relief. If the lumps are too deep, consult a dermatologist as they might require more specialized treatment.

No obvious cause, and no specific time, could be very itchy at the leg.  There is a mass of lightly colored red rashes when starting.  It starts to get deeper in color and raise above skin surface, forming a bump.  It is itchy all the time.  Once scratching, it is expanding to a much larger area, with irregualr shape.
This picture shows 3 days after the onset of the disease.  The following shows the fourth day.  Look, it becomes more red in color, and starts to shrink in area.  The edge is getting clearer, and more shiny on the surface. A faint red spot in the middle can also be seen. The temperature of the affected area is getting higher, itchy......
Two days pass, it is starting to subside on the 6th day.  The red spot in the middle can be clearly seen, which is the place most itchy.
The 2 pictures following show the situation on the 7th day.  The 3rd batch is for the 9th day.  The small red spot is still there, but less itchy.
On the 17th day, there is not much feeling.  Yet it is still there, subsiding slowly, and not itchy any more.
3 months later, a few of them are coming up, all at the lower limbs, with one on the front left arm.  They are not that severe, not symmetrical, but very itchy.  Have tried loratadine and cetirizine and other topical creams, with not much effects.  I think this is Type 4 hypersensitivity reaction.  If it is not properly handled, could result in the formation of large amount of immune complex damaging my weak liver.  Ahh..  Are there any professional dermatologist that can help on this.  I am in internal medicine, not good on that.

Is this herpes zoster?

Found two blisters near my ribs when I bathed.  It is not itchy or painful.  Before that, in the summer last year, I inadvertently found two blisters similar to that.  It was on the outer side of the pelvis, and was not itcy or painful.  I thought it was herpes back then.  It subsided a few days after I applied acyclovir topically. It came back a couple of times after that.  But it also subsided without any intervention.  It is dark purple in color.  Have tingling pain after the blister is poked open. Never happen in winter.  It relapsed last month. It appeared on the outer side of the pelvis when starting, and subsided a few days later.  It is coming back these days, and at the edge of the ribs.  There is no improvement after using acyclovir.  May I ask experts here if this is herpes zoster or pompholyx?  I went to the hospital today to get a routine blood test and C-reactive protein.  They revealed no problem.  The physician said it is mite infection, and prescribed Valacyclovir, Loratadine, and topically drugs to protect skin and mucosa.  I don’t feel good with this diagnosis and use of medicines.  But I will try it first and hope that the problem does not come back.

See picture for the disease

The patient is female, 48 years old.  Blisters are coming up on both upper limbs and soles.  It is itchy.  Shown in the  picture is when they are broken open.  Would experts here help on that.

Is this acute eczema or herpes simplex?

I am 19 years old, male. There grew 4 unequal dark red marks on two cheeks of my face about half a month ago.  I thought they are acne at the begining.  2 to 3 days later, skin was peeling with discharge of pus. I, myself, think this is eczema.  What medicine is good for that, including oral and topical use medicines?  Please advise in detail.
text: The image shows dark red or purple spots on the skin, which are possibly acne or eczema. The skin appears to be slightly pus-filled, and the area is surrounded by a ring of red. In either case, the presence of pus suggests that the skin is inflamed.

prompt:
Skin lesion at the finger.

Dear brothers and sisters.  I have a very troublesome problem, and hope that you can help me to solve it.  Thank you in advance.

I am an overseas student in Europe.  I work part time at a Chinese restaurant there.  My duties include: washing glasses, ashtrays (I am not using detergents), waiting tables etc.  Right from the time I started working, my hands start to be torn out (see picture below).  At the very beginning, it is shredding skin little by little, until the whole area with finger print is completely off. (First from the ring finger, then the middle finger and then the index finger.)  What is left behind turn very hard, rough and it starts cracking, bleeding and very painful.  The skin is coming out layer by layer.  This causes great inconvenience to my daily life.  If I stop working, it heals gradually.  The problem comes back after I start working again.  It is the same even if I change to another restaurant. 

I have seen dermatologist here.  He/she didn't say anything special, just advised that I have been using too much soap.  I was prescribed two drugs. One for the day and another for the night.  The day time drug contains carbamide.  There is some minor pain when rubbing it onto my hand, but shows some improvement.  I don't know much for the ointment for use at night, but it is not helpful at all.  I don't know who can help me, telling me what disease it is, and what treatment is needed.

P.S.  I have a friend who has the same symptoms.  She told me the problem is gone that after taking a drug by the name of Sporanox .  I am not sure if I should take this drug.  Also this drug can not be purchased from pharmacy without prescription from a physician.

Thank you again for the help.
text: 湿疹，不一定是药疹，建议查过敏原

text:
The image shows a close-up view of a person'#s backside, focusing on the itchy rashes that are more dense around the waist. 

The presence of rashes could indicate a skin condition, such as eczema, caused by a reaction to an external factor, or it could be due to an infection. It is essential to identify the exact cause to provide proper treatment and minimize the risk of recurrence.

prompt:
I got a small red nevus on my chest.  What is the cause of this?

There grows a small mole in skin on the front side of the chest.  What is the cause for that?
text: The small red nevus on the chest is a common growth, which can be considered a beauty spot. It is not a cause for concern. The mole on the front side of the chest is more of a concern. It may be a benign or malignant growth. If it is benign, there is no need to worry. If it is malignant, it may require treatment.
